Ok, I don't think this is the place for it, as this is about racial preference, but what the hell.
Schools, your parents, your friends teach you to be afraid of failing. School chastises you if you get the answer "wrong". Your parents chastise you for doing something the "wrong way", your friends emotionally hurt you if you do things "wrong". This builds the idea that their is a right way to do things and a wrong way to do things, in EVERYTHING, and doing it wrong is emotionally charged with negative feelings. Therefore we avoid the "wrong" like the plague, even at the behest of learning something new. The irrefutable process of learning is paved with mistakes. We have to make them in order to gain the desired outcome that we are after. However school instils in us or conditions us to think that in EVERTHING their is a perfect answer surrounded by wrong ones. I could go deeper with things like all reality is an imperfect reflection of the idea, as it lives in perfect form, in the world of ideas, but that's too much for this! Suffice to say, not everything has a right and wrong answer.

When I say that ethnical preference degrades the individual, the very notion of grading something as part of a group of things, even slightly, restricts its individuality, does it not? It can no longer be seen as separate from something, it is part of the group. All I am doing is asking about what you think about it, how it is framed in your mind. If you feel that you do not wish to divulge or its personal or whatever, that's cool. I was just after understanding your view point.
I think sometimes people are taken aback by me, because it seems that the norm is that people don't give two s**ts about the ideas of others, just their own, whereas I like to explore what other people think about things and see if it makes sense to me. It helps me clarify my own thinking. However, if I have evidence that something which has been expressed is incorrect factually, I present it. But I am under no illusions that I am right, I am always open to the possibility that I have it completely incorrect, or that another way of thinking is superior to my own, and the only way to find that out is through debate. It's helpful in my goal to be the most knowledgeable version of myself that I can be. This then helps me to able to discern fact from fiction, which then in turn helps me to make the best possible choices. It also helps me with debating and exercising my brain. All bonuses in my book.

No worries about the "mess of words" :) I can get your meaning. For once, a little bit of debate with a slice of differing opinions without name calling and mud slinging. :) I think we all do have biases, even ones we are not aware of. I think this is what really contributes to us preferring a skin colour over another, or just completely dismissing a skin tone as potential dating material, rather than the innocuous "I like what I like answer". I think that answer tends to shy away from the idea that we have any choice and therefore no responsibility about who we are attracted to. However I assert that we have more control over such a thing than we admit, and that a lot of the time its other peoples influence over us that dictate our attraction, or who we are willing to admit to ourselves who we are attracted to. Take for example the man (or woman) who is of the mind that they are hetrosexual. Their minds will filter out the members of the same sex that they are attracted to, to maintain the idea that they are hetrosexual. This will continue until they have gained an awareness of self and realise that those same feelings of attraction that they feel for the opposit e sex, they also feel for the sa me sex. I use myself as example, it has taken me twenty one years to realise I find men attractive. However I will not sleep with a man, due to my own fears of w hat sex would be like. I also find women incredibly attractive also and because of this you could accuse m e of sexism which I think would be true, but I wont hide behind double talk and denial, I will hold my hand up to it. In that same way, I think that people are naturally attracted to people, rather than ethnicity (which makes more sense to me than being attracted to a sp ecific ethnicity, since we have no gene for that) but we apply our own filter to decide that we don't want to find that person attractive, so we ignore the feelings. But even then, at some point, this will change. This is because our list of attraction changes over time and our awareness deepens. When you look back at the people you dated when younger and you think to yourself, whatever did I see in that person . As we age, our attraction widens. Why?

No I'm not confused, just ready to admit things to myself that when I was younger would not have noticed at all. I suppose I am more bisexual than anything, but as you may or may not be aware a movement has been building towards non-binary definitions of sexuality. This is nothing new really, maybe to Western audiences, but the native Americans already had non-binary sexual definitions for centuries. As usual the pushback is happening, but I think as time progresses it will be another thing people will become comfortable with, but it will still have its staunch oppositionists, much like this discussion abou t race and relationships. Anyways, cool chatting with ya Freddy. Catch you on the flip flop. I think we have said almost most of the things others might have said.
